stream_context.summary: Kaze focuses on late-stage polish and bug-fixing across existing levels while building out Course 11’s oil-rig interior: adding a slide entrance into a sub-area, designing/implementing new hydraulic “piston” platforms with variable timing, and iterating on oil/boiling-tar visuals. Along the way he discusses N64 texture-memory constraints, RTYI-specific warp parameters, animation/door issues blocked by Lilaa’s quaternion exporter, and broader plans like open-sourcing the code and starting an Unreal Engine project + Kickstarter after RTYI ships.
level: Course 11 – Oily Boily Bay (oil rig interior)
stream_context.significance_reason: Contains multiple documentary-relevant insights: concrete N64 constraints shaping art, engine-level RTYI changes (warp params), a clear difficulty/design philosophy, public-source vs PC-port stance, and post-release business planning (Unreal demo + Kickstarter, possible soundtrack album rights).

findings.summary: Kaze is in a broad stabilization phase: going through levels “from correspond to the last person” and fixing bugs so every level can be beta-tested.
He’s been self-imposing daily deadlines for two weeks and says he has hit every one so far; next deadline pairs bug-fixing with blocking out the “OBB underground.”
Course 11’s sub-area is designed with a forced slide entry: there are three entrances into the sub-area but only two exits, creating a consistent “sent down the slide” feel on entry.

RTYI warps require extra configuration beyond vanilla SM64: Kaze added two additional warp parameters—(1) warp-object height/hitbox and (2) the camera angle you receive when exiting a warp—meaning existing warps often must be redone to avoid incorrect behavior.

N64 texture-memory limitations strongly constrain asset choices: he hits TMEM limits (e.g., 4096/4096 bytes) and resorts to unusual resolutions (e.g., a “cursed” 96×42 texture) and i4/IA-style compromises to fit multiple textures.
findings.quote: This is the most cursed texture resolution I've ever seen. My 96 by 42 texture.

findings.summary: He adds moving machinery primarily to sell the oil-rig fantasy: implements multiple hydraulic/piston platforms with intentionally unsynchronized rhythms to make the space feel like independent machines running.

To make piston platforms workable, he fixes a culling bug by enlarging the culling radius instead of recomputing each tick (“cheap-out” approach), and then addresses incorrect update order by changing spawn/update sequencing (using a spawner approach).

Door/animation issues remain partially blocked on tooling: Kaze says doors are “fucked up” due to animation changes and that a proper fix is waiting on Lilaa’s quaternion animation exporter; otherwise they risk redoing work later.
findings.quote: Until we have Lilaa's quaternion animation exporter, we cannot fix the doors.

findings.summary: He plans to make RTYI’s source code publicly viewable, but doubts a true PC port will happen due to required skill/time; he considers bundling an emulator “silly.”
findings.quote: I will make a public source… but I seriously doubt anyone is gonna have the skill to make a PC port of this, or the patience.

findings.summary: He outlines a post-RTYI strategy: start working on an unrelated Unreal Engine platformer demo, and when RTYI releases, launch a Kickstarter for that Unreal project to fund future work and give the team more creative freedom.
findings.quote: Simultaneously with the release of Return to Yoshi's Island we are going to start a Kickstarter for this game in Unreal Engine.

findings.summary: He articulates his approach to difficulty curves: he doesn’t increase difficulty for its own sake; instead, he pushes “cooler” (harder) jumps later and lowers the “coolness threshold” early so levels stay enjoyable. He also includes optional assist movement for weaker players, but wants players to feel free to use movement without sacrificing completion goals.
findings.quote: I don't try to make the levels more difficult. I just put the threshold of how cool a jump has to be… lower.

findings.summary: Player-flow philosophy: the game boots directly into file select (a 3D level like Mario Sunshine) to avoid wasting time; he prefers death returning players to the hub/level start to preserve impact and let them choose a different destination.
findings.quote: The game doesn't waste your time. That is important to me.

findings.summary: Progress estimate: he reiterates a plan of 15 courses and suggests the overall project is roughly 75–80% complete (with substantial earlier effort spent on engine/tooling). He floats ~180 stars as a possible target.

He identifies remaining work for Course 11’s theme mechanics: an “oil puddle enemy” concept (likened to 3D World-style blob enemies), soap-bar respawn/cleanup tuning, and visual polish for boiling oil/tar with reflections, bubbles, and possibly smoke.

He considers a RTYI soundtrack release where he pays the musician(s) for rights and releases an album; he imagines an N64-cartridge-themed “album” concept (even as a ROM acting like an MP3 player), but questions legality.

biobak.summary: Biobak provides art/asset iteration support in real time: Kaze checks whether a highly constrained re-resolution (96×42) works and requests a Blender file for a sail model so he can attempt texture/implementation adjustments.
Biobak is directly involved in fitting textures to N64 constraints (format choices and downscaling), with Kaze repeatedly asking if certain cursed compromises are acceptable.

zeina.summary: Zeina is referenced as remembering an older, now-missing “Hot Tub Mario” mod, indicating she tracks/participates in Kaze’s broader mod history even when not speaking on stream.

findings.summary: Lilaa is developing a quaternion animation exporter that Kaze treats as a key dependency for properly fixing doors/animation issues without doing rework.
Lilaa was absent for about a week; Kaze and chat jokingly acted as if she had died, then she reappeared in chat, confirming she saw the “RIP Lilaa” post and was fine.

key_stories.title: Building hydraulics under strict N64 texture limits
key_stories.summary: While dressing Course 11’s oil-rig interior, Kaze wants more moving machinery, especially hydraulic/piston platforms. The visual idea collides with N64 texture memory limits, forcing aggressive texture-format choices and strange downscaled resolutions.
key_stories.challenge: Make new machinery look convincing and varied without exceeding N64 TMEM limits and while keeping the art style consistent.
key_stories.process: He audits texture memory usage in tooling, explores combining textures and i4 constraints, then settles on an extreme but workable resolution (96×42). He iterates on the piston look (accordion/hydraulic vibe), then implements the behavior with variable speed/pause parameters and fixes culling/update-order bugs that emerge.
key_stories.outcome: A workable hydraulic platform system is in place with culling issues addressed and update-order partly corrected; visuals still need polish, but the area’s vibe improves significantly with rails and moving parts.
key_stories.key_quote: This is the most cursed texture resolution I've ever seen. My 96 by 42 texture.

key_stories.title: Animation/door fixes blocked by quaternion exporter dependency
key_stories.summary: Kaze notes recurring issues with doors and animations being “fucked up” due to changes in animation handling. He frames Lilaa’s quaternion animation exporter as the clean solution; otherwise any workaround risks being thrown away later.
key_stories.challenge: Fix visible door/animation problems without creating rework once new tooling arrives.
key_stories.process: He identifies the dependency explicitly on stream and chooses not to fully finalize certain fixes until the exporter exists, implying a deliberate sequencing of polish tasks around tool readiness.
key_stories.outcome: Doors remain imperfect for now; the team is waiting on the exporter to lock in a proper fix path.
key_stories.key_quote: Until we have Lilaa's quaternion animation exporter, we cannot fix the doors.

key_stories.title: Post-RTYI funding plan: Unreal demo and Kickstarter
key_stories.summary: Kaze describes a plan to start an unrelated Unreal Engine project (a platformer demo) before RTYI finishes, then launch a Kickstarter for the Unreal game around RTYI’s release. The goal is to generate funding so the team can work with more freedom on future projects.
key_stories.challenge: Sustaining long-term development and monetization beyond a ROM hack while keeping RTYI on track.
key_stories.process: He clarifies this is not an Unreal port of RTYI; it’s a separate game. He also mentions the need to manage open-source/public code access in parallel.
key_stories.outcome: A concrete roadmap emerges: RTYI release as a springboard into an original commercial project funded via Kickstarter.
key_stories.key_quote: Simultaneously with the release of Return to Yoshi's Island we are going to start a Kickstarter for this game in Unreal Engine.

open_questions.topic: RTYI warp system changes and level-production impact
open_questions.context: Kaze added two warp parameters (warp-object height/hitbox and exit camera angle), and says many warps must be redone because older placements lack these settings.
questions: When did you introduce the extra warp parameters, and what problem(s) were you solving compared to vanilla SM64?
How much level rework did this create (number of warps/levels affected), and did it change how you design transitions/camera reveals?
Were there any bugs or player-experience issues that convinced you the extra warp parameters were worth the added authoring cost?

open_questions.context: Kaze repeatedly ties door/animation correctness to Lilaa’s quaternion animation exporter, implying the pipeline currently can’t export or represent some rotations reliably.
questions: What exactly breaks in the current animation pipeline (gimbal issues, interpolation artifacts, door hinge rotation, etc.) that quaternions will solve?
How did this dependency shape your scheduling—what polish tasks are you intentionally postponing to avoid rework?
What is the expected integration process once the exporter is ready (engine changes, re-exporting existing animations, regression testing)?

open_questions.topic: 30 FPS mode lag and planned threading change
open_questions.context: Kaze mentions speedrunners report 30 FPS mode lag and says he plans to restructure so the gameplay thread becomes part of the rendering thread (or vice versa) to improve FPS.
questions: What is the current architecture of gameplay vs rendering threads in RTYI, and what specifically goes wrong in 30 FPS mode?
What measurements or reports from speedrunners drove this investigation, and how will you validate the fix?
Does this change risk timing differences that affect movement consistency or speedrun tech?

open_questions.topic: Open-source release goals vs feasibility of PC ports
open_questions.context: Kaze intends to make the source publicly viewable but doubts anyone will port it to PC due to complexity; bundling an emulator feels pointless to him.
questions: What do you want the public source release to enable (education, community mods, transparency, preservation)?
What parts of RTYI’s engine modifications make a PC port especially hard (hardware assumptions, RSP/RDP specifics, asset pipeline, threading)?
Are you planning a specific license or contribution model, and what would you accept/avoid from community pull requests?

open_questions.topic: Soundtrack rights and ‘album on an N64 cartridge’ concept
open_questions.context: Kaze suggests paying the musician(s) for rights and releasing an RTYI album, potentially themed as an N64 cartridge (or a ROM that functions as a music player), but he’s unsure about legal feasibility.
questions: What rights do you think you’d need to clear (original compositions vs arrangements, performance rights, distribution), and who would own what?
Would the album be purely original compositions for RTYI, or include remixes/derivatives that could raise Nintendo/IP concerns?
If the ‘cartridge album’ is more of an art object, how would you manufacture/distribute it without crossing legal lines?
